characters: YORK, A WELCOME AWAITS YOU AT THE TIMES SQUARE PALACE HOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Susskind-type MODERATOR is speaking into camera:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight we'll discuss a subject most of us seem to consider either bad taste or frivolous or funny. But if our experts are right, we face what might be called a masculinity crisis. Every fourth American man uptight, threatened by the increasing sexual demands of American women...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An IRATE WOMAN speaks into camera:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They always put it that way, but well, all it means, you know, is every fourth American woman's never satisfied. That's it. I never am -- have been, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A COOL WOMAN speaks into camera:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This, this image of the, the man eating woman. It isn't our increasing demands. I think it's the shrinking American male...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SAD WOMAN speaks into camera:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I never had, well, whatever it is you call it. But the hours he works, I can't blame him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full frame -- a scandal sheet picture of a sex-starved wi naked while her husband sleeps, captioned I BUY WHAT MY HUSBAND CAN'T GIVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but it's a problem. A big problem. With so many women I know... Camera pulls back to show the picture among other pinups women -- rich, beautiful or naked, but all blonde -- stea wilted on the wall over a dishwashing machine. JOE BUCK g at the wall as he scrapes garbage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just keep your pants on, ladies...

dialogues.speaker: MULTIPLE SPLIT SCREEN
dialogues.text: A LADY COMMENTATOR, gradually surrounded by lonely women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before World War One -- American men outnumbered women by over six percent. Today American women not only outnumber men, but live five years longer -- leaving them in control of vast corporate wealth and seventy-five percent of America's purchasing power... The Lady Commentator is replaced by Joe, stacking dishes, surrounded by frustrated ladies. He laughs tolerantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all,line up and take your turn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Moderator smiles into camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My question is this -- will American know-how come up with a marketable male to replace all the men who are worrying themselves into an early grave over women's increasing sexual demands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sings as he soaps himself, "Whoopee ti yi yo, git alo little dogies, for you know New York will be your new hom Sound and image freeze on Joe's open mouth.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSED MAIN TITLE AND CREDITS
dialogues.text: TITLES follow as indicated, sound and action continuing a each credit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's song continues over a sweating WAITRESS, glancing u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that Joe Buck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrapped in a towel, singing in front of his dresser mirro Joe sprays himself with deodorant, aiming a last playful blast at the unseen crotch -- freezing song and image as CREDITS continue over... ... a calendar girl on the wall blushing orange, mouth fr in a tiny O, staring wide-eyed. Joe's song continues as.. ... Joe rips the wrapping from a new Stetson and sets it his head, freezing song and image as CREDITS continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RALPH, an aging black man, faces a mountain of dirty dish

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that Joe Buck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Singing as he buttons his new cowboy shirt, Joe interrupt himself to answer Ralph...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, where's that Joe Buck? ... continuing his song as he pulls up and zips his tight thighed black slacks, freezing song and image for CREDITS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SALLY BUCK, a pretty middle-aged blonde, smiles down at camera,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look real nice, Joe baby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sings as he pulls on his new cowboy boots, arranging cuffs to show off the yellow sunburst at the ankle, freez song and image for CREDITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pink MANAGER scowls at his pocket watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that Joe Buck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe hums as he piles a complete wardrobe of cowboy clothe still in their wrappers, into a shiny new suitcase of bla and white horsehide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, where's that Joe Buck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding his watch, the Manager wags a finger at camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're due here at four o'clock. Look at those dishes, look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe laughs as he locks his suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what you can do with those dishes? And if you ain't man enough to do it yourself, I'd be happy to oblige... Joe picks up his suitcase, a portable transistor radio, w away from the mirror, then pauses to run a comb through h hair, hook a cigarette at the corner of his mouth and str a match on his thumbnail before he turns back for one admiring glance at himself in the mirror -- proud, exulta ready -- freezing the image as CREDITS END.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe leaves the hotel, carrying his suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pink Manager points at his watch angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four to midnight, understand? Angle widens to include Joe, holding his suitcase and rad Ralph stares at him curiously, stacking dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, look, uh, I gotta have a word with you, if you got a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Later maybe. The Manager hurries away, carrying a basket of dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't coming to work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't guess. Just come for my day's pay owing and to tell you I'm heading East. Joe tilts his Stetson as the Waitress appears at the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cups! ... but she disappears without noticing Joe. Ralph offers hand. Joe takes it, holds it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you gonna do back there, East?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotta rich women back there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men, they mostly faggots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be some mess back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, ain't no use hanging around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't gonna collect your pay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got me two hundred twenty-four bucks of flat folding money...  (slaps hip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He know what he can do with that chicken-shit day's pay. And if he ain't man enough to do it for himself, I be happy to oblige!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door marked EMPLOYEES ONLY swings open and Joe appear measuring his effect on the customers and his fellow employees as he crosses the sterile white dining room, observing the drab details of the life he has left behind garbage on greasy dishes, limp food in steam table trays, coffee-soaked cigarette butts, caked mustard and ketchup formica table tops -- two pimply high school girls slurpi suggestive noises after Joe through the straws of empty c glasses. O.S. a Tiomkin-tradition chorus sings, "From thi valley they say you are going -- we will miss your bright eyes and sweet smile for they say you are taking the sunshine..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song ends as Joe comes from the cafeteria "... that brightened our pathway a while."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough tiddy, ladies, you had your chance. From a high angle -- Joe starts his long walk toward the depot along the street of a small Western town struggling urbanize itself. The click-clack-click of his boots is lo but somehow lonely The radio at his ear drones grain pric on the Commodity change. Joe's pace slows as he passes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... a gilt-lettered sign in the window, glittering in the sun, momentarily hiding the fact that the shop is deserte Joe grins as he hears remembered sounds and voices incomp flashes, more significant in tone than content a girl giggling sexily -- "Keep your meat hooks off my beauty operators, sugar" -- tinkling noises of a busy beauty par - Sally Buck singing "Hush, little baby, don't say a word Grammaw gonna buy you a mockingbird..." ... a shift of light revealing a row of tarnished driers, broken mirror, a FOR RENT sign in the window. Joe turns toward the bus depot, radio pressed to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benson and Hedges One Hundreds makes special awards from time to time for anything that's longer than anything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Care to get out your yardstick, gentlemen? At the same moment, a recognizable variant of the "Big Country" theme blares loud.

dialogues.speaker: WESTERN FILM CLIP
dialogues.text: Gary Cooper (or John Wayne) walks a frontier street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High angle of the departing bus, intercut "Big Country" fashion, alternating high shots with close-ups of the bus wheals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the bus windshield -- a dizzying montage of traff lines, arrows and signs as the bus sweeps around and up o the freeway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits at the front, opposite the driver, cracking his as he watches the huge billboards streaking by, promising power, happiness and beautiful women if he chooses the ri breakfast food, hair oil or automobile. Joe listens to th humming tires, the roar of the engine, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a powerful mothah, ain't it? Ignored by the driver, Joe rises and walks back to his em double seat, glancing around to see what impression he's on his immediate fellow travelers -- an OLD LADY in front him -- a hostile young sailor with acne behind him -- two teeny-boppers flirting with Joe hysterically -- a PALE BL directly across the aisle, smiling at Joe weakly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a stick of gum? Joe leans across, snapping his gum as he offers her a sti He watches her nibble it daintily on her front teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty more where that came from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, no, it's just till the Dramamine works. I get carsick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only get carsick on boats.  (waits, then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But seems to me that's more the fish smell than the bouncing... Joe realizes that her eyes are closed. Mildly depressed, stretches himself across both seats and turns on his radi finds only static and snaps it off. Further depressed, he examines his reflection in the bus window, squeezes a bla head and runs the comb through his hair, picks a piece of tobacco off his tooth and lights a cigarette, watching th flame die in reflection, forgetting to discard the burnt- match as he stares out at a vast lonely prairie, a solita cowboy in the distance, a row of sharecropper shacks apparently deserted, a barefoot little girl motionless at roadside, watching the bus pass. Through this, leading in the next scene, Sally Buck sings softly "... if that mock bird don't sing, Grammaw gonna buy you a golden ring..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally Buck, relaxing in the middle of a busy day, eyes cl wearily, while little Joe massages her neck. Her song continues over the noises of the busy beauty parlor "... that golden ring turns brass, Grammaw gonna buy you a loo glass..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, a little lower, sugar, yeah, yeah, that's good. Grammaw's beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta sell yourself, that's the whole trick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A seedy TRAVELING SALESMAN with badly-fitted dentures and frayed collar has taken the aisle seat next to Joe. As he lectures Joe on salesmanship, he figures his expenses in worn leatherette notebook, nervous fingers and eyes unconsciously revealing the extent of his failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't the product and it ain't the price, no sir, and it ain't what you sell, it's personality, pure and simple. I ain't shined my own shoes or shaved my own face in forty years, how's that? Not bad for a kid that didn't pass the eighth grade, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, hell, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's my golden rule. Make 'em love you. Put yourself over and you can sell them anything. If they like you, they'll buy horsemeat for prime beef...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gawky, adolescent Joe sits sprawled on the couch, leafi through a magazine while Sally Buck bleaches the roots of young woman's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get him to the church, honey. He ain't gonna find out you ain't a real blonde till after you're married, then's too late. Sally Buck turns, pretending to be stern as Toe laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You getting too big for your britches, sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headlights of the bus flash past a huge sign, painted the slant roof of a barn: JESUS SAVES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is alone again. The Salesman has disappeared. The bus dark, most-passengers trying to sleep. Only one reading l still burns, over the head of the old-Lady in the seat ah of Joe. Joe squirms, restless, trying to lull himself to sleep with the music of a revivalist gospel group on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget to say your prayers, honey... Joe leans forward to help the old Lady, irritably struggl with the release button on her seat. She scowls as Joe le over to release her seat, then pulls her blanket around h and turns away from him. Joe switches off her reading lig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want it on. Joe switches it on again, fakes a good-natured grin, sett back with his radio, aware of an OLD COWHAND seated oppos him, replacing the Pale Blonde. The Old Cowhand is apprai Joe's wardrobe curiously. He looks away when he sees Joe watching him. Joe settles back, unable to think of a way open a conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my friends, I say unto you, invest with Jesus, put your dollars to work where they'll pay off at compound interest. The Good Book says money answereth all things... The Old Cowhand has rolled-himself a cigarette. Joe quick lights a match on his thumb and holds it across the aisle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light? The Old Cowhand's "thanks" is lost in a fit of coughing a inhales his first drag. He settles back, wiping his water eyes on a faded bandana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... everyone who sends a dollar to the Evangelical Congregation of the Air will get free gratis a genuine leatherette hymn book so you can sing along with Sister Rosella and the Evangelical Choir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You throw in Sister Rosella and you got a deal, right, old timer? Joe glances across the aisle. The Old Cowhand manages a faint, humorless smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up the line. Not far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm bound for New York City. The Old Cowhand reappraises Joe's wardrobe even more curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever happen to come across a cowman name of Woodsy Niles? Friend of my grammaw Sally Buck... The Old Cowhand considers, shakes his head. Joe leans bac laughing to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Joe's head is lost in a beat-up cowboy hat, simila the one worn by the old Cowhand. Sally Buck smiles on WOO NILES -- a long-legged cowboy with a shock of black hair who stands at her dressing table, admiring himself in a n Stetson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like it, honey? Does it fit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do me good, Sal, you do me real good. You know what I gonna give you for that Stetson? Woodsy grabs Sally Buck, lifting her off her feet, carryi her to the bed. Struggling, they fall across the covers together, Little Joe laughing with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woodsy Niles! The boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't know what makes little apples by now, it's time he found out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe shakes his head, grinning, offering the old Cowhand a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke? The old Cowhand shakes his head, showing the rolled cigar Joe lit for him. Joe nods, still bemused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Joe is cuddled in Sally Buck's arms, under the cov watching Woodsy, sitting cross-legged on the bed, naked except for his Stetson and guitar, singing drunkenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... git along little dogies!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a high angle -- the bus slows to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe awakens, stiff-necked, momentarily confused. He straightens in his seat as he sees the old Cowhand liftin sweat-stained saddle down from the overhead rack, startin toward the front of the bus. Joe calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice talking to you, old timer. Joe stuffs a stick of gum in his mouth, turns to wave at Old Cowhand through the window as the bus pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She-dogs squat, boy. He-dogs stand up and lift their leg...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woodsy, in his new Stetson, watches Little Joe in his bea cowboy hat, trying to balance on one foot, one leg lifted front of the trough. Woodsy roars with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but he-men stand and shoot from the hip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe laughs, flushes, checks his hair in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus streaks past a brightly-colored billboard -- IN N

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is now sitting in the wide rear seat, between two you MARINES and a group of VETERANS wearing campaign caps and convention buttons, passing a bottle, singing "From the B of Montezuma to the Shores of Tripoli..." Joe follows the conversation between a VETERAN and a MARINE, participatin only because he's sitting beside them, adopting a remembe military stance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever stationed at Kennedy? Those Florida chicks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instant V-goddam-D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Pensacola teeny-bopper -- jail bait -- but built? Ten bucks she wanted. Three of us made a deal for, twenty-five, see, big goddam bargain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big peni-goddam-cillin bargain, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus goddam Christ, I ain't laughed so hard since I was out at Fort Benning, Georgia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you make the Viet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Oh, hell no. Motor pool mostly... (shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kee-rist...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plump, aging PROSTITUTE laughs up into camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, what you try to do to me? You gonna cost me money, soldier!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe laughs as he passes the bottle, trying to sing along without knowing the words as the Veterans segue into "Ove hill, over dale, we will hit the dusty trail, as the cais go rolling along..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally Buck fondly wipes lipstick from Joe's lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your meat hooks off my operators, sugar, hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe slaps one of the Veterans on the back, trying to foll the song into "Off we go, into the wild blue yonder..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANASTASIA clutches a younger Joe, eyes wild, gasping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the only one, Joe, the only, only one ever!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is leaning across the two Marines, staring out of the window as the Veterans switch to "Anchors aweigh, my boys anchors aweigh..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stunning view through the bus window past Joe's reflect

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna swing my lasso and rope that whole goddam island, yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drum majorettes leading the parade -- ticker tape and confetti -- girls at skyscraper windows.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSREEL CLIP
dialogues.text: Charles Lindberg (or James Stewart) waving at the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls lining the piers -- flags, banners, bunting -- ship horns, whistles, bells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe crowded as the veterans prepare to leave the bus, lif down banners and flags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus suddenly surrounded by converging traffic, horns honking, segueing into the noises of Times Square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flag draped, reading: WELCOME VETERANS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flapping in the wind -- WELCOME VETERANS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marquee announces TRANSIENTS WELCOME. O.S. a singing radio station break blares "W-I-N-S NEW YORK..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sign flashes WINS "... ten-ten on your dial!" A torch woman's voice sings from a lonely echo chamber -- introdu a love theme which will haunt Joe throughout the film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sets his radio on the dresser, his suitcase on the be then turns to examine his new home -- as anonymous as his Texas hotel room -- but boasting a coin-operated televisi set. Fascinated, Joe inserts a quarter. ... the love song continues over a television talk Show featuring a POODLE WIGMAKER defending his profession agai a Joe Pyne-type PANEL HOST, "...well, I perform a real service, there's a need, so many people, you know, really live in their pets, I mean, lonely, I grant you, but thei feeling is real. They want to lavish as much love, give t as much, yes, pamper them like they were really human children or whatever..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a TV dinner in the fridge, lover boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Joe stares sullenly at an antique TV box while Sal Buck puts her hat on at the fireplace mirror. There is a framed picture of Woodsy Niles on the mantle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You be okay, won't you? Maybe I bring you a treat if you're a good boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe watches the Panel Host, "... you're a nut case, fella real nut case..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Joe massaging Sally Buck's neck -- continuing the earlier scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so beat, no point you waiting round, toots, think I'll stop in for a beer or two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits on the edge of the bed, watching the poodles pri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Joe stares unblinking at the TV screen as Sally Bu kisses him on the forehead, dressed for the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Expect me when you see me. Looks like I got me a new beau, lover boy, how's that for an old grammaw? I'll leave you movie money... Sally Buck tucks a dollar bill under a framed picture of Jesus, who has replaced Woodsy Niles on the mantle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a fairy godmother's magic wand removes sticky hair spr from a pretty model's head, Joe's quarter runs out and th screen goes blank. At the same moment, the love song is c off by a singing station break "W-I-N-S NEW YORK" Joe ris flipping the dial of the radio to a cultured woman's voic reading "...the Dow Jones averages, brought you by Morgan Vandercook. Up your income with sound investment counseling..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up yours, lady. ... but Joe leaves the lady on, savoring the expensive so of her voice reading the stock quotations. Joe seats hims at the desk, pleased to find a postcard photograph of the hotel. He picks up a ballpoint pen, counts ten floors up the street and marks a huge X -- THIS IS ME, then turns t card over, pen poised over the address blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph stares at the card, surrounded by dirty dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, he know I can't read...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's pen wavers, starts to write and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we saw it last, deserted, a FOR RENT sign in the windo Joe's reflection appears, staring at himself, dressed in dishwasher's clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all them dishes are washed, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they bring some more dishes and I wash them and then I, uh, sleep some and then wash some more dishes and then I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it, lover boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe stares at the postcard, bemused,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you better just shake your tail, lover boy, and root, hog or die. Joe rises abruptly, rips up the postcard and tosses it ou the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddam if I came to this town to write postcards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The torn fragments flutter down on the crowd -- a woman brushing irritably at her hair -- a man grimacing, glanci up -- a cop removing his hat to examine it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a low angle -- identical with the postcard photograp an unseen hand scrawls a huge X--- THIS IS ME. Camera zoo up to a close-up of Joe at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From on high -- as though Joe were watching himself -- th Stetson moves through a crowd of Fifth Avenue shoppers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... passing a glass bank, lady tellers counting money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... passing a display of imported luxury cars...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... passing a window which features a single gem -- pausi as horns blast O.S. and a mod blonde in a stalled sports motions to Joe -- she needs a push. Joe grins, glances at himself in the window, runs a comb through his hair, then turns back to see a cop helping the mod blonde.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's heels drag as he walks a deserted block of luxury apartment houses. O.S. The torchy woman's voice sings Joe love theme in counterpoint to the blasting horns, a siren fire bell, a screech of brakes. Joe's spirits rise as he hears the tic-tac-tic of high heels overtaking the heavy click-clack-click of his boots. He adjusts his pace to ar at the corner at the same time as a smart and -- in Joe's eyes -- very RICH LADY. Joe grins boyishly, holding his Stetson over his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beg pardon, ma'am, I'm new here in town, just in from Houston, Texas, and looking for the Statue of Liberty. The delicate profile gives no signs of hearing. Joe follo her to the parkway in the middle of the avenue. There she stops and turns, neither friendly nor hostile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you looking? About the Statue of Liberty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joking? No, ma'am. Oh no! I mean business!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I thought you were -- never mind -- I've never actually been there, but let me see, you take the Seventh Avenue subway, I think, to the end of the line...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure are a pretty lady. The Rich Lady tries to frown, taken aback, blushing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not looking for the Statue of Liberty at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ma'am, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, that's perfectly dreadful. Aren't you ashamed of yourself? A twinkle of amusement and sympathy reveals the age lines the corner of her eyes. Then she continues on quickly, ju as the light turns. Joe's view is blocked for a moment by traffic, then he sees... ... the Rich Lady, newly aware of her flanks as she climb the steps of a brownstone and searches for her key. Still from Joe's viewpoint, he sees himself move into frame and follow the Rich Lady up the steps. The love theme swells as the Rich Lady leads him into the house and closes the door... ... leaving Joe standing alone on the parkway island, surrounded by towering wealth. The love theme continues over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... a pair of high-heeled pink slippers, walking a miniat poodle -- slowing slightly, reacting to Joe's cowboy boot they pass, pause and turn back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up, Baby. Do um goody-goods for Mama. Joe grins, holding his hat over his heart as he approache CASS TREHUNE, a blonde lady in a tight black dress, with look of a movie star who wrecked her career with food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beg pardon, ma'am. I'm brand spanking new to this town, come  from Houston, Texas, and hoping to get a look at the Statue of Liberty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're hoping to get a look at what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Statue of Liberty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's up in Central Park, taking a leak. If you hurry, you'll make the supper show. Now get lost. But as she turns, Cass winks, dimpling the corners of her mouth, signaling Joe to follow her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cass holds the DOOR OPEN button till Joe enters the eleva then the doors close with a soft expensive little kllooos and Cass turns with the smile of a very tiny girl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. ... her lips closing on Joe's as the poodle yaps shrilly their feet. Superimposed, almost subliminally, a golden dollar sign appears, halating like a star, and the bell o pinball machine rings O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A princess telephone is ringing on a gold and white desk. Cass runs to grab it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? ... as Joe steps from the elevator, which opens directly Cass's penthouse. Cass beckons him toward her, hooks a fi into his neckerchief and pulls his mouth toward hers whil she talks on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morey? Hi-ee, honey... Cass gurgles happily as her free hand unbuckles Joe's garrison belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just out of breath, honey, running to catch the phone. As her fingers reach for Joe's zipper, cut to... ... Joe's hand unzipping her dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was walking Baby. Him got to do him goody-goods, right? The poodle tugs at Joe's slacks until they fall. Cass ste her ear to Joe's mouth, shuddering deliciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, oh stop. I can't stand that. I just die... (quickly into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Baby, Morey. Him trying to say hello. Say hello to Morey, Baby. Cass holds the phone toward the yapping poodle, twisting herself against Joe as she wriggles out of her dress, pas the phone from one hand to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, old goosie? Now lookie, when do you want me to meet you? Whatever you say. I'll take a nap, watch TV, you know, kill time. Okay, but just one, a big wet one. Cass hangs up. The poodle yaps hysterically, disentanglin himself from her tumbling dress -- hops onto the couch  glances off and flees again as an overturned lamp crashes O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poodle bounces onto the bed -- remaining long enough establish a TV REMOTE CONTROL TUNER lying on the satin coverlet -- then leaps down in panic as he hears Joe and explode into the bedroom, laughing lustily... ... the remote control tuner buried suddenly under the fu flesh of Cass's hip, activating... ... a twenty-five-inch television screen, blasting at ful volume... ... Cass's eyes widening, profoundly impressed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ye gods... ... the images and sound of the television set flicking joyfully from channel to channel... ... Joe laughing, engulfed by Cass's abundance... ... Cass wild-eyed, overflowing the frame... ... a gleaming slot machine -- three Sahara cowgirls clic into line for jackpot -- silver dollars overflowing the frame...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the Mutual of New York tower flashes MONY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shee-it, this is a goddam penthouse you got here, Cass, a real goddam penthouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe turns away from a small terrace, buckling his belt, glancing off toward the sound of Cass in the shower. He flicks the TV remote control, enjoying his power, ignorin the silent images on the screen -- battle casualties, a pretty girl recommending aspirin, a man's stomach flashin animated pain, starving war refugees, a dog eating pzazz flicking it off to concentrate on the costume jewelry and perfume bottles on Cass's dressing table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look, baby... Joe turns to look as Cass comes from the bathroom, holdin towel around her as she runs behind the closet door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Cass, I, uh, sure have enjoyed being here. Believe it's as fine a time as I've had in my life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too, lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good, it is, cause, well I guess I didn't tell you why I came to New York, did I? A tower of black bugle beads emerges from the closet door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zip this thing, will you, Tex? Joe zips her dress, follows her to the dressing table, wh she sprays her hair with lacquer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truth is, Cass, I'm, well, I'm in business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, poor you. Morey's got terrible ulcers. Cass stretches her upper lip across her teeth and she sme it with, orange lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know what line Morey's in, but myself now, fact is -- I'm a hustler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lips stretched)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hers'n zodda meg a livig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beg pardon, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said, a person's gotta make a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you heard what I said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scuse me, hon, fraid I'm only half here. Maybe you oughta run on along. But why don't you take this phone number? Joe grins, relieved as she takes out a gold lame purse an opens it. He frowns as she folds; it upside down, empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darn! I didn't get to the bank -- Tex -- could you let me have a little coin for the taxi-waxi? Joe stands mute as she cups his chin in her hand, seductively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're such a doll. I hate money, don't you? God, it's been fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny thing, you mentioning money. I was just about to ask your for some... Joe tries to laugh but it sticks in his throat as Cass sp -- an impassioned whisper -- still holding Joe's chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bastard! You son of a bitch! You think you're dealing with some old slut? Look at me! You think just cause you're a longhorn bull you can get away with this crap? Well, you're out of your mind. I am a gorgeous chick, thirty-one, that's right, you said it! Sobbing suddenly, she throws herself on the bed. Joe stan bewildered by the vastness of her grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Hey, Cass. Did you think I meant that? Christ, would I be asking you for money with a wad like that riding on my hip? Joe waves his wallet at her, but she only cries louder. H hands her a kleenex. She clutches it to her face, wailing Joe leans over the bed, whispering in her ear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. You are a gorgeous-looking piece, Cass. Guy gets horny, just looking at you. It's a fact. How much you need for that taxi? Ten? Twenty? There you go. Joe tucks a twenty-dollar bill into her bosom, tilts his Stetson and starts out. Cass blows her nose, looking afte him. O.S. chorus sings, "From this valley they say you ar going -- we will miss your bright eyes and sweet smile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a high angle, Joe walks away from the apartment hous chorus continuing O.S. "... they say you are taking the sunshine that brightened our pathway a while."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits at the bar, staring morosely at his image in the mirror, already quite drunk, oblivious to the assorted ty hiding from daylight in the barn-like saloon, waiting for night to fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I'm just admiring that colossal shirt... RATSO studies Joe across the corner of the bar -- a sickl child-size old man of twenty-one -- hopefully nursing an empty beer glass, contemplating the money on the bar in f of Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is one hell of a shirt. I bet you paid a pretty price for it, am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it ain't cheap. I mean, yeah, I'd say this was an all right shirt. Don't like to, uh, you know, have a lot of cheap stuff on my back. Ratso spits as JACKIE leans on the bar next to Joe -- a feminine young person, heavily made-up, hair teased, wear earrings and a lace-trimmed blouse over shocking pink  le

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a cigarette, cowboy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a stage whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More goddam faggots in this town. Reaching for a cigarette, Joe glances at Jackie, startled Jackie twitches his pink levis angrily and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shee-it... (shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kee-rist, you really know the ropes. Wish to hell I bumped into you before. I'm Joe Buck from Texas and I'm gonna buy you a drink, what do you say to that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enrico Rizzo from the Bronx. Don't mind if I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slaps bar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same all around! For my friend, too! The TV screen over the bar features a mating game program Jackie cruises down to join a tall farm boy with plucked eyebrows. The TV HOST points to three young men, visible from the shoulders up, from whom a pretty DATE GIRL in blindfold must choose an escort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and for the losers, who don't get the girl, we'll give as consolation prices -- a six month supply of underarm deodorant... In a booth now -- the TV screen in the background, contin the game -- Joe is refilling Ratso's beer glass as he spe loud over the laughter of the TV audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... you see what I'm getting at here? She got a penthouse up there with color TV and more goddam diamonds than an archbishop and she busts out bawling when I ask for money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For money for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a hustler, hell, didn't you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would I know? You gotta tell a person these things  (shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hustler? Picking up trade on the street like that -- baby, believe me -- you need management.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you just put your finger on it, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend O'Daniel. That's who you need. Operates the biggest stable in town. In the whole goddam metropolitan area. A stud like you  - paying! -- not that I blame you -- a dame starts crying, I cut my heart for her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd call that a very minor operation... Ratso grabs the neck of a bottle, sliding back in the boo Joe scowls as Jackie appears with the tall farm boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... in fact, you just sit comfy and I'll cut it out with my fingernail file. You won't even need Blue Cross, Ratso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name is Rizzo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I said, Ratso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey now, you heard him. On the TV screen -- the Date Girl announces:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pick Number Two! He's cool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, Joe. I'm used to these types that like to pick on cripples. Sewers're full of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask one thing, cowboy? If you sit there and he sits way over there, how's he gonna get his hand into your pocket? But I'm sure he has that all figured out... (to Ratso)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, sweets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May present your chosen mate! The TV host pulls aside the screen which has concealed th lower half of the three young men. Number Two, her chosen mate, is a dwarf sitting on a high stool. The girl's spontaneous dismay starts everyone laughing hysterically, including the dwarf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe has difficulty keening up with Ratso, who swings hims along with surprising agility, his half skipping little g favoring one game leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, with these chicks that want to buy it, most of 'em are older, dignified, right? Social register types. They can't be trotting down to Times Square to pick out the merchandise. They need a middleman, right? That's O'Daniel. Joe hesitates as Ratso darts into traffic against a red light, yelling unheard obscenities at a cab driver who bl his horn. Joe runs recklessly forward as Ratso slams the fender with his fist, pretending to be hit, falling into Joe's arms. The taxi stops, halting traffic. Ratso, recov strolls casually in front of the cab, biting his thumb at driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a crime, a stud like you passing out double sawbucks to a chick like that. With proper management you should be taking home fifty, a hundred bucks a day. More if you wanta moonlight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At,the corner of Central Park South, Ratso points toward young man with diamond cuff-links, sitting with a blue-ha matron who puffs on a small cigar. Ratso waves jauntily a the young man, raising his thumb and forefinger in a circ leaving the young man baffled as Ratso hurries Joe on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him I placed with O'Daniel just two weeks ago. And look. Not much of a stud either, what I hear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso automatically checks the coin return boxes of the p booths they pass. Walking the park side of the street, looking across at the limousines and taxis waiting outsid luxury hotels and apartment buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, listen, how about you take me to mee this Mister O'Diddle bird right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Joe, you're a nice guy, and I'd be doing you both a favor, but why? What'm I dragging my bum leg all over town for? It's no picnic and what for, for me myself, what? Ratso stops opposite the Plaza hotel, pointing across at aristocratic blonde stepping out of a Rolls Royce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow when some piece like that's scratching your back in a Fifth Avenue townhouse, where'll your pal Rizzo be? Nedicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it, just hold it. You think I'm that kinda sombitch? Just name your cut, whatever you want, you got it right now. Five? Ten, how's that? Joe peels a ten from his wallet and offers it to Ratso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, please. You know what I'd ask anyone else? Oh hell, tell you what I'll do, I'll take the ten... (he does)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but when I hand you over to Mr. O'Daniel, I'll have to have another ten, Joe; just to like cover expenses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso is on the phone. Joe holds the door open, listening

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This boy is just your meat, Mr. O'Daniel, believe it, I'm telling you -- what? -- Enrico Rizzo from the Bronx. The point is he needs you. Right now. Tonight... (aside to Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got his tongue hanging out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera moves slowly up the anonymous wall of a drab hotel following the line of dim red lights marking the fire exi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name's Joe Buck. Cowboy. Just in from Texas, don't know the ropes, new to the city, but very promising material, sir, and ready, if you get what I mean. Fabulous. Right away. What's that room number there again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As ancient open cage lift rises at the same pace as camer preceding shot. Joe grins excitedly at Ratso, who nods bu glances significantly at the elevator operator. Ratso fol Joe to door as the operator grinds to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso steps out with Joe, gesturing to the corridor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it a second... ... but the operator slams the door and starts on up. Rat leans heavily on the down button, glancing at Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine-oh-one, got it? Ratso glances up the elevator shaft nervously, rings agai and turns back to Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see how you look. Fine. You look fine. Now I'm gonna have to have that other ten...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (digs in wallet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten, ten -- I got a twenty -- take that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hell, forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now take it. Go on.  (gives it to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, where can I reach you? Cause I'm gonna make this right with you soon's I get me set up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, dammit, where you live? Ratso leans on the DOWN as the cage grinds slowly down in view and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherry-Netherlands Hotel. Now get your ass in there. He's waiting! Ratso steps into the elevator as the door opens then clos leaving Joe alone, repeating "Cherry Neverlin" as he star along the corridor looking for 901.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso bursts from the hotel, almost running as he disappe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe finds 901 at a dark end of the corridor, knocks confidently, hearing a few bars of his love theme as he stuffs a fresh stick of gum in his mouth. Then the door i thrown open by O'DANIEL -- for an instant appearing to we diamond-studded skull-cap, the naked overhead light bulb bright after the dark corridor, halating in Joe's eyes li the earlier dollar sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be Joe Buck. Come in.  O'Daniel, fat in a worn-out bathrobe, examines Joe like a prodigal son as he leads him into the room -- as anonymou Joe's own room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I tickled to find you, boy! Come on in and let's get a look at you. Turn around. Good strong back. You'll need it. So you want help -- take a seat, relax, tell me about yourself. Cowboy, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir, I'm no cowboy really, but I'm a first class stud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it,easy, boy...  (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems to me you're different than a lotta boys that come to me. Most of 'em seem troubled, confused, but I'd say you knew exactly what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet I do, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'll bet you got one thing in common with them other boys. I'll bet you're lonesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not too, I mean, a little. O'Daniel rises suddenly in a fury of self-righteousness, pacing, his voice simpering, whining sarcastically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm lonesome. I'm lonesome so I'm a drunk. I'm lonesome so I'm a dope fiend. I'm lonesome so I'm a thief, a fornicator, a whore-monger. Poop, I say, poop! I've heard it all and I'm sick of it, sick to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir, I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonesomeness is something you take. You bear? Dammit, you take it and go about your business, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh, I'm raring to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I believe you are. Cowboy, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yessir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready for hard work, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a hunch, Joe Buck, it's gonna be easier for you than most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna be like money from home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money from home, see, there's your strength, you put things in earthy terms any man can understand, son. I warn you I'm gonna use you, I'm gonna run you ragged! Joe laughs, driving an obscene uppercut into the air. O'Daniel laughs with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a wonderful boy. You'n me gonna have fun, dammit, it don't have to be joyless. Say, why don't we get right down on our knees now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get down -- where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here, why not? I prayed in saloons, I prayed in the street, I prayed an the toilet. He don't care where, what He wants is that prayer. O'Daniel drops on all fours, crawling to find the plug of electric cord. He shoves it into a wall socket, switches the overhead light and suddenly a hollow, tinted plastic Jesus glows on the dresser. O.S. a revivalist congregatio sings. And now we notice, with Joe, placards and flags, h and tracts, all the paraphernalia of a street corner evangelist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shee-it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the ticket, just open your heart and let it flow. It ain't the words, it's the love beyond 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally Buck sings with the congregation while a rawboned preacher stands in the river, preparing to immerse little Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fight it, boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Daniel tries to pull Joe down beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray and you shall be heard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera becomes little Joe, glimpsing the fevered faces of Sally Buck and the congregation singing on the riverbank, just before being plunged under the river. O'Daniel's voi reechoes, filtered through water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be frightened, son!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe runs in aimless panic, pushing through the crowd, pur by O'Daniel's voice and the singing congregation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't run from Jesus! Joe stops short as he sees the front page of a tabloid on newsstand. There is a picture of Joe being led away by tw deputies, under a headline ALABAMA MURDERER SHOTGUNS ELEV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe searches the faces of the crowd, running forward sudd as he sees Jackie and the farmboy picked up by two men in large convertible. Joe chases the car to Eighth Avenue bu stops, frightened as he sees himself in multiple image on front of every newspaper displayed on a newsstand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The saloon is almost empty during the after dinner lull. BARTENDER doesn't look up from his newspaper as Joe approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, you know that runty little bastard I was with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know nothing. Joe tenses as he sees the . tabloid picture of himself on back of the bartender's paper. Joe's hand closes around a empty beer bottle, a terrible violence surging very near surface. O.S. women scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reflected in the mirror, we see little Joe wildly smashin bottles and glass display cabinets -- the voices of women screaming O.S. -- little Joe hurling a perfume bottle whi shatters the mirror and his own image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The empty beer bottle stands where it was. Joe has disappeared. On the TV screen over the bar, sound drowned by the jukebox, we see a blowup of the tabloid photograph revealing a young man very similar to, but clearly not Jo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colorful lights still flash seductive promise. The vertic lights on the MONY tower reach bottom and freeze momentar

dialogues.speaker: STILL PHOTOGRAPH
dialogues.text: Joe at his hotel window staring out blankly. Gun fire O.S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radio at Joe's ear is drowned out by a kid in cowboy shooting alone in the gallery. Two policemen idly slap their thighs with night sticks. J moves on, unconsciously checking the coin return box of a phone.

dialogues.speaker: STILL PHOTOGRAPH
dialogues.text: Joe curled up on his bed like a baby, fully dressed, his radio on the night stand. O.S. his love theme, remote, hollow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's radio is at his ear "... never too late to look gre Ben's Bargain Basement's open 'till five a.m., miles and miles of Western styles, worth more at any store, money t and nobody walks." For the first time, Joe is aware of th other midnight cowboys lurking in doorways, the cruising queens, the middle-age men in sport shirts. Joe moves on consciously as he sees a scar-faced policeman, unconsciou massaging his night stick. Camera holds on a window displ of gag buttons, featuring NEW YORK WILL BREAK YOUR HEART, BABY.

dialogues.speaker: STILL PHOTOGRAPH
dialogues.text: Joe soaking in the tub, eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's radio promises job opportunities for young men eigh to twenty-five in the U.S. Air Force. He stands with a cr staring up at a girl go-go dancing in the window of SERGE PEPPER'S LONELY HEART CLUB.

dialogues.speaker: STILL PHOTOGRAPH
dialogues.text: Joe staring in the mirror. O.S. static over his love them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By work-light, the tarrier in metal helmet leans on a jac hammer, beyond the sign DIG WE MUST, drowning out Joe's radio.

dialogues.speaker: STILL PHOTOGRAPH
dialogues.text: Joe flexing his muscles in his jockey shorts while -- LIV TV SCREEN -- a physical culture personality finishes push and starts pitching his own extra protein bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's radio continues the super-break commercial while a cook flips flapjacks in the window. But Joe's eyes are on a sign DISHWASHER WANTED. Joe looks and his eyes meet those of the young man scraping garbage behind the counter. It's Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shee-it.

dialogues.speaker: STILL PHOTOGRAPH
dialogues.text: Joe sits in the hotel lobby, staring out at the street, unable to concentrate on his comic book. On two-way radio woman's voice giggles as she speaks, "When I can't sleep, well, I just dial the time and listen to those old second clicking by like, you know, counting sheep?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe watches a young man hold a taxi door for an older lad at the same corner where Ratso waved to another young man The woman's predatory eyes linger momentarily on Joe befo she leads the young man into the Cafe. The two-way radio continues over, "... that's what I do about insomnia."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now, ma'am, next time you got that feeling coming on, you dial Joe Buck. I'll show you what to do...

dialogues.speaker: STILL PHOTOGRAPH
dialogues.text: Joe straddles a chair, staring at a blank TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need a little easy money? It's E-Z. Want a little easy cash? It's E-Z.

dialogues.speaker: E-Z LOAN COMMERCIAL
dialogues.text: As the jingle continues, we follow Joe and his radio into loan office, the depressing reality photographed and edit in the style of a TV commercial:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy locations to get to  Easy ladies to greet you  Easy chairs to seat you  Easy payments to meet  Let E-Z set you  On Easy Street  Joe arrives confident       Harassed E-Z receptionist      Lines of uneasy customers        Desperate, angry faces         Reams of E-Z forms to fill   Clerk's sneer, says                 Joe has to be kidding

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's image frozen -- as if another still photograph - standing at the desk, waiting for his key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Key to 1014... Action continues as the DESK CLERK hands Joe a folded pap instead of a key. Joe opens it, deeply perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like you been locked out of your room, buddy. Till you pick up your tab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, what about my things'n all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We keep them nice and safe till you get this straightened out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room 1014 warm and inviting, Joe's suitcase on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, tell you what, you can keep all the rest of the goddam junk if you let me have just the suitcase. That suitcase means a lot to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The postcard photograph marked X -- THIS IS ME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We keep everything. House rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe stands outside the hotel, stunned, seeing the bright colored lights turn suddenly grey. The film continues in black and white as Joe walks into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FOR RENT sign flapping in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe nurses a short beer, like the regulars. He looks up a crippled panhandler approaches, vaguely reminiscent of Ra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bed turned back, clean sheets, a soft night light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is stretched on a bench, his Stetson over his eyes. A loud speaker announces a bus "departing for Texas" but Jo does not move. A policeman taps Joe's boots with his nigh stick. Joe rises and starts away with mixed anger and apprehension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two matching Ivy Leaguers exchange a glance as they see J washing his feet in the basin. Joe stares back with a belligerent grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any objection, gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe balances a cup of coffee, walking past the other soli night people, avoiding each other's eyes. Joe spots what looking for and seats himself next to a gaunt woman and h ten year old son, both freaked out, erratically touching things, themselves, each other in a futile effort to make contact with reality. But Joe is only concerned with the plastic-wrapped crackers left by their empty soup bowls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'ain't gonna eat them? The woman stares at Joe blankly. The boy runs a toy mouse across the table, up his mother's arm and around her face With a polite nod, Joe opens the crackers and squirts one with ketchup. Joe upsets his chair as a great gob of ketc spills onto his pants...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shee-it. ... glancing around with an embarrassed laugh, but the on one looking is a cop, scratching his calf with a night st Joe keeps his back to the customers as he moves to the wa dispenser, wets a paper napkin and tries to wipe away the stain. But the water has only spread the stain across his pants and down his leg. He blushes as a blonde young streetwalker giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wet your britches, lover boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe tries to hide the stain with his jacket as he checks coin boxes of vending machines, wary as he passes a burly policeman, abstractedly snapping his handcuffs in front o bakery window display of bride-and-groom wedding cakes. J barely glances at a confused MIDDLE-AGE LADY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I get to Grand Central?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shuttle. Follow the green light. Automatically,checking the trough of a gum vending machin Joe unexpectedly faces himself in the mirror, the eyes staring at him tired and hopeless. His hand reaches unconsciously for a cigarette, The package is empty. He crumples it in his fist but holds it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, cowboy. Enough of this shee-it. You know what you got to do?  (nods) Then go do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe hurls the crumpled package into a DON'T BE A LITTERBU basket as he emerges from the subway, his radio at his ea The torchy voice belts his love song, merging with street noises crying danger -- an ambulance, a burglar alarm, a policeman's whistle -- the lights flashing lurid color fo the first time since Joe was locked out, no longer promis but threatening, clashing, warning as... ... from a high angle, across the street, Joe joins the o midnight cowboys, offering himself to all comers. His fig is momentarily obliterated by traffic then... ... zooming in, we see Joe self-consciously trying to hid the stain on his pants, embarrassed as a large sedan slow then moves on to stop in front of a motorcycle freak. Joe briefly obliterated again by a passing police car... ... the receding flash of its turret light revealing Joe close conversation with a frightened young FAT BOY, whose eyes plead for reassurance as Joe scowls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's black and white suitcase gleams on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-three bucks, I got to have twenty-three bucks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From an apparently empty balcony -- an old science fictio film grinds endlessly through the night -- a lost spacema trying to make contact with a tantalizing Martian maiden across an invisible time barrier, theremin voices calling "Earthling, where are you?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Sure. I got twenty-five... At the top of the balcony, Joe leans back, turning his fa away as the Fat Boy embraces him, kissing Joe's cheek and neck, his head moving down out of frame to show -- on the screen -- the spaceman and Martian maiden meeting, arms outstretched. But the Martian maiden moves right on throu the spaceman, crying, "Earthling come back, however many centuries it is, I'll wait!" Joe closes his eyes, forcing memory back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... repeating the remembered image of Anastasia and a you Joe, behind the movie screen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the only one, Joe, the only, only one ever! ... the remembered passion continuing, mounting -- interc with flash impressions, like flipping pages of a nudie magazine -- naked, half-draped blondes gazing into camera with sultry eyes, including one comic strip sexpot and th calendar girl in Joe's Texas hotel room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the best, the very best, yes, yes, kiss me, oh God please kiss me, Joe, now, now, now! ... Joe's face in extreme close-up, sounds of both movie houses merging, confused, dominated by the voices of adolescent boys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Joe, give someone else a chance! What's he doing for chrisake? He kissing Anastasia? You better swallow a whole goddam drugstore, man! ... an adolescent ratpack waiting in line behind the scre laughing in coarse whispers, watching Joe and Anastasia. theremin voices call "Earthling, where are you?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On screen, the Martian maiden moves through the spaceman, crying, "Earthling, come back, however many centuries it I'll wait!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe watches the Fat Boy doubled over, retching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm awful damn sorry you're sick, kid, but you gonna have to gimme that money like you said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was lying. I don't have it. What're you going to do to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (controls fury) What you got in your pockets? Eagerly, the boy produces a family photograph, a subway token, a dirty handkerchief. Joe grabs his wrist, reveali watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much's that worth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't go home without my watch! My mother'd die! She'd die! Take my books! Not my watch! She'd die! But Joe has already kicked open the door. Theremin voices drown out the Fat Boy, calling "Earthling, where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sprawls, trying to sleep, his feet on the balcony rai the radio at his ear. On screen, once again, the Martian maiden moves through the spaceman, crying, but we hear th voice of a desperate woman on two-way radio. As she speak policeman moves along the aisle, slapping his palm with h night stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, can I call you Bill, Mister Bonner? I feel like I know you from listening. What I called about, Bill, I'm gonna kill myself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a high angle, only Joe's Stetson and radio can be se above a passing bus, its side panel advertising BILL BONN STRAIGHT LINE, A STRAIGHT TALK SHOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why call me, baby? If you want to do it; just do it, don't talk about it. Are we drunky? Feeling a little sorry for ourselves maybe? Joe appears in full figure as the bus passes. He stands looking at the suitcases in a luggage shop window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Bill, what I got thinking, I didn't want the neighbors to have to find me, this young couple with the boy I want to have my cat, see, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BONNER, tough in a grey crew-cut, talks on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, baby, now listen, just hold on while I leave the line for a minute. And think about all the kids that are dying overseas for you, okay, baby? Got that? I'll be back in exactly sixty seconds. After this message from... A taxi born blasts, interrupting the sponsor's message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's fist slams a fender violently, using Ratso's fake injury trick to stop traffic, running across the street toward...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Ratso staring out at Joe, paralyzed in the act of lighting a cigarette -- intercut in flashing close-ups -- outside the window, Ratso inside -- reflecting their conflicting emotions -- Joe's murderous rage -- Ratso's p -- one almost subliminal flash of each revealing somethin like pleasure at finding a long-lost friend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Ratso staring up into camera, holding his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't hit me, I'm a cripple. Joe's hand falls on Ratso's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I ain't gonna hit you, I'm gonna strangle you to death... The cigarette in Ratso's mouth burns into his lip. He jer spasmodically, choking on smoke as he rips skin away with butt and drops it in his coffee cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... only first I'm gonna turn you upside down and shake you out right here and now. Coughing, eyes tearing, Ratso empties his pockets on the counter, finally producing: sixty-four cents, a few stick gum, an almost empty cigarette package, a book of matches two pawn tickets. He raises his eyes, somehow ashamed. Jo kicks the toe of Ratso's loafer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in your socks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a cent, I swear to God, I swear on my mother's eyes. Ratso removes his loafers and shakes them, glancing at th counter man. His socks don't even conceal his toes. Disgusted, Joe shoves Ratso's small pile back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep the sixty-four cents. I want you to have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's sticky. What you do, slobber on 'em? I wouldn't touch 'em. Joe should leave -- Ratso obviously has nothing tangible offer -- but Joe hesitates, lighting a cigarette as Ratso pulls on his loafers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like that O'Daniel, flipping out like that? I wanted to get in touch with you when I heard, but I been laid up with this cold... Ratso touches his chest, forcing a cough which continues itself beyond his intention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want some free medical advice, shut your goddam mouth about that night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, right, right, okay. Another subject. Where you living? Still at the hotel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black and white suitcase lies open on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe turns abruptly and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shee-it. I got better things to do than talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe strides north, pretending he doesn't hear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wait up, for crissake! ... Ratso hop-skipping to overtake Joe at the traffic lig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, keep away from me, hear? You come near me again, I snatch you bald-headed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm inviting you. I mean if you're not located, I got a place. I'm inviting you, goddamit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You inviting shee-it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A contractor's sign announces LUXURY APARTMENTS AVAILABLE high-rise co-op, under construction beyond a raw of tenem with X's taped on the windows. Ratso's voice continues ov the click-clack-click of Joe's boots and the flip-flap-sq of Ratso's loafers as camera moves toward a condemned building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The X on the window means the landlord can't collect rent -- which is a convenience, hey? -- on account of it's condemned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footsteps climb past rubbish piled outside empty flats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The electric's off. Another convenience. I don't mess with Con Edison, hey? What the hell, I got candles, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light from the X window shines on a Florida tourist poste Ratso leads Joe into an abandoned tub-in-kitchen flat, ba furnished with a table and chair, a rumple of blankets on burnt-out mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got no heat, but by that time, you know, cold weather, hey, I'll be in Florida. Stretch out. Make yourself comfortable. You hungry? I'll put up some water for coffee. Ratso fills a saucepan from the tub-sink, sets it on a St stove. Joe sits himself on the mattress-bed, pretending t test it, weeks of exhaustion and tension overwhelming him suddenly, his only immediate problem being the effort to restrain a large, comfortable yawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comfortable, kee-rist, I slept on subways softer than this. Joe stretches himself, yawning, his eyelids drooping heav The sounds of the city recede. Joe's love theme plays sof on a distant radio. Joe's eyes close momentarily in spite him elf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vintage dashboard, radio dial glowing, Anastasia's face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love me, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge metal ball arcs on chain, demolishing a brick faca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso's face seems to radiate evil as he lights a Sterno Joe forces his eyes half-open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smart thing for me to do is haul ass outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatsa matter now? Joe shivers, pulls a blanket around him, resisting sleep, the noises of demolition fade, the love theme lures Joe b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't seem like no fag...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean? Joe's eyes close, his voice continuing out of half-sleep.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Want me to stay here, y'after something. What y'after?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's thumbnail flares a match, exposing Anastasia on the seat with Joe, both nearly naked. Anastasia butterfly-kis Joe's chest as he lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: ANASTASIA
dialogues.text: Say you love me. Just say it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Okay. I love you. Anastasia purrs as her lips find Joe's breast, trying to nurse. A flashlight flares suddenly through the car windo

dialogues.speaker: NIGHTMARE
dialogues.text: Low angle Ratso bending over Joe, into camera... ... Sally Buck shocked, hand still on switch...  ... Joe blinded by halation...  ... Anastasia's mouth screaming soundlessly...  ... flashlights multiplying on car window... Full frame -- Anastasia catatonic in hospital gown -- a woman's voice "What'd he do to you, Annie?"... ... gang-bang ratpack surrounding car with flashlights... ... Jackie shrieking "He loves her he loves her"...  ... hands closing on Joe's buttocks...  ... hand closing on Joe's naked left foot...  ... hand on naked right foot...  ... dentist leaning over Joe's mouth...  ... hands pulling Joe's legs apart... Zoom close-up -- Anastasia screaming soundlessly... ... thermometer under Little Joe's tongue...  ... Sally Buck shoves chocolate in her mouth...  ... bewigged poodle licks her fingers...  ... Sally Buck hangs enema can on bedpost...  ... Ratso leads ratpack chasing naked Anastasia...  ... corona of flashlights... Anastasia screaming soundlessly -- flashlight shoved into mouth -- electronic rock blasting... ... blank-eyed go-go girl in dance hall window...  ... Joe held naked by ratpack...  ... Ratso breaking beer bottle on Everett's bar...  ... dwarf laughing on television...  ... Ratso aims broken bottle at Joe's crotch...  ... shooting gallery cowboys riddle Joe's pelvis... Anastasia catatonic in courtroom -- between gaunt parents whining singsong "Raped her raped her Joe Buck raped her" ... Fat Boy's mouth finds Joe's breast, tries to nurse... ... Sally Buck kisses him open-mouthed...  ... slug crawls up Joe's stomach, trailing mucus...  ... Cass's poodle laps at his toes...  ... butterflies settle on his eyes... Anastasia catatonic in courtroom between parents -- who a now O'Daniel and Sally Buck... ... drawling voice "evidence of repeated violations"...  ... Bill Bonner in flag-cloth judge's robe...  ... police advancing, swinging night sticks...  ... Joe running into Times Square, suddenly naked...  ... Anastasia sitting in all-night cafeteria...  ... freaky child running toy mouse over her naked body... Siren screaming -- Anastasia staring catatonic from rear window of ambulance... ... ambulance racing away...  ... Joe chasing naked after ambulance...  ... running into the arms of the police...  ... Ratso laughing as police beat Joe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe awakens in a cold sweat, fighting the blankets, wild- as he sees Ratso at the table, examining Joe's radio by candle-light. Joe lunges across the room to snatch the ra from Ratso's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For crissake! Still wild-eyed, Joe suddenly points at his stocking feet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my boots -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe facing the crowd, naked except for his boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso points to the boots on the floor by the mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd they get off me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took 'em off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you could sleep! I mean Christ! Joe inspects the boots, seats himself on a battered Army - which has been added while he slept -- swinging a boot its strap, considering whether to stay or go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I drug in a cot, if you want to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
