dialogues.text: Well now, Ratso, I'm gonna tell you something for your own good, only first gimme a cigarette. Ratso offers a cigarette from his crushed package, Joe strikes a match on his thumbnail and lights up, staring a Ratso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to stay here tonight, is that the idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't forcing you, like, I mean, who's forcing you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Guess I got the wrong impression. Joe makes a slow move to pull on one boot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to stay, okay? I goddam invited you, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I hope you know what you're in for. I'm a very dangerous person. Someone does me bad like you. If I caught up with you that night, there'd be one dead Ratso long about now. Hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm impressed. You're a killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if you want me to hang around for a few days, I thought you should know. Joe yawns, picks up a few blankets and spreads them on th cot. He puzzles out the faded printing on one blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Property of the YMCA. You make me wanna puke sometimes, Ratso. Ratso blows out the candle and wraps himself in blankets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe -- do me one favor -- this is my place, am I wrong? You know, in my own place my name ain't Ratso. I mean it so happens my name is Enrico Salvatore Rizzo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shee-it, man, I can't say all that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rico then, at least call me Rico in my own goddam place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rico! Rico! Rico! Is that enough? (then) And keep your meat hooks off my radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso wears a threadbare raincoat of faded black, several sizes too large, as he shops with housewives at a sidewal vegetable stand -- elbowing his way through the ladies, testing fruit, picking up vegetables and putting them bac till the GREENGROCER spots him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You! Out! Out! I told you, I calla cops! The other shoppers deliberately turn their backs, avoidin involvement. As the Greengrocer grabs Ratso, Joe ambles i the scene, wearing his dangerous little smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, looka here, that ain't nice, picking on a cripple... Joe intervenes just long enough for Ratso to escape, then ambles on, leaving the Greengrocer in frustrated fury. Ca holds on a tray of coconuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe lies on his cot, watching Ratso struggle to penetrate fibrous husk of a coconut, experimenting with a variety o rusty tools in an old cigar box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two basic items necessary to sustain life are sunshine and coconut milk. That's a known fact. If I can find the goddam hole the milk squirts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an okay setup you got here, but I'd say you ain't just exactly, uh, flush, is that right or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been sick. Hold this, will ya? Joe takes his time rising to hold the coconut while Ratso tries to poke a hole with a bent ice-pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Florida, they come smooth, ready to eat. Down there, your only problem is, diet-wise, you gotta lift an arm to wipe warm milk off your chin. Tough, hey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think finding you's the smartest thing I ever did, for both of us. You just the crooked kinda sneaky little sidewinder I need to get me hustling in this town. Hey! Joe jerks his hand away just in time to avoid the ice-pic The coconut bounces on the floor. Ratso picks it up, hold it, while Joe tries to crack it, swinging his boot like a hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miami Beach is the only place for a real hustler. Florida has more rich chicks per square yard than any resort spot in the world. They lie out in their pagodas and pergolas waiting to grab the first jockstrap that passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all this sweet talk about Florida? Your friend O'Daniel got a stable down there now? Joe swings violently. Ratso yelps, hopping on his one goo leg, sucking his thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cowboy killers! Break my finger, Christ! I got news for you, baby, no chick with any class buys that big dumb cowboy crap... Ratso holds his thumb under the tub-sink faucet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the cowboy bit's out, except among fags of a certain type, which take a certain, type hustler to exploit. Like I could handle it -- being a stealing operation basically -- but take your average fag, very few of them want a cripple. Joe holds the coconut like Yorick's skull, thinking hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I am dumb, that's for sure. I don't talk right. I can't think too good. Just only one thing I ever been good for's loving. Women go crazy for me. Fact. Crazy Annie. Had to send her away. So I don't cash in on that, what am I? I'm shee-it. May's well flush me down that hole with the dishwater. Joe sets the coconut on the floor, holding it with both h while he tries to smash it with the heel of his boot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why you gonna stop crapping about Florida and get your skinny butt moving to earn twenty bucks worth of management you owe me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The suitcase lies open, displaying Joe's wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make that twenty-three bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe slams his heel down. The coconut shoots out from unde him and he lands on his ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at yourself, Joe, no offense, but frankly, you're beginning to smell. For a stud in this town that's a handicap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk like a man with a tin twat. Ratso sets the coconut on the window sill, balancing it a raises the X window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't got a chance in hell. You need threads and glitter, baby. A front, hey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh, my manager's gonna manage all that crap, or else he gonna get a coconut up his flue. Joe slams, the window down. The coconut flies down to cra O.S. on the sidewalk below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An alley cat laps up the milk of the broken coconut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe stands naked in the middle of traffic. A siren shrill Anastasia, catatonic in a hospital smock, moves toward Jo like a sleepwalker, passing through him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing only his boots, Joe sits like an Indian chief, wrapped in a blanket -- angle widening to show Ratso, spotting Joe's jacket, slacks and shirt with cleaning flu his eyes on a very pregnant Italian lady. As she starts t load a coin cleaning machine, Ratso intervenes solicitous speaking in Italian...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman in your condition shouldn't do that. Let me help... ... adroitly slipping Joe's cleaning in with her load as turns to seat herself beside Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't right, stealing from a pregnant lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Ratso stand waiting at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did it cost her? The laundromat syndicate lost a couple coins. I'm crying. The owner brings Joe's clean and blocked Stetson from the rear of the shop. Joe sets it on his head and examines himself in a mirror as the owner hands Ratso, the bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's mine? The black homburg? I brought it in the same time. The owner glances at the slip, puzzled, returns to the re of the shop to search for the nonexistent homburg. Ratso quickly drags Joe away from the mirror and out of the sho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rhythmic duet of boots and loafers follows Joe and Ra - checking coin boxes and telephone booths -- till they r a shoeshine stand, locked for the night. They loiter till young couple has disappeared, then Joe kicks loose 'the padlock on the equipment drawer, mounts one of the chairs Ratso goes to work on his boots with furious expertise, flourishing double brushes, snapping the rag like a jazz drummer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you're good! I bet you could pick up a living at this if you tried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And end up a hunchback like my old man? You think I'm crippled? You shoulda caught him the end of a day. Ratso demonstrates a chimpanzee walk. Joe laughs. Ratso t back in panic as another man takes a chair next to Joe. R is about to retuse when a cop takes the third chair, swin his handcuffs around to the front, tapping his shoe with night stick. Ratso quickly drops a rag over the broken padlock, cursing under his breath as he starts working on three customers at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it's funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is seated in a straight-back chair near the X window, towel tucked around his neck as Ratso trims his hair, alm as expert a barber as shoeshine boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid bastard coughed his lungs out breathing that resin all day. They buried him with gloves on. Even the fag undertaker couldn't get his nails clean. As if by conditioned reflex, Ratso chokes on the cigarett his mouth, coughing painfully. He crushes it out, opens t window to spit, shivering, then slam it and turns back to remove the towel from Joe's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kee-rist, you pretty damn clever for a skimpy little gimp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like it? Take a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't rush me. How I do it, see, I get myself primed, like I was turning on the charm for some pretty little blonde lady, then kinda mosey away slow and easy and  - swing around! -- and there you are, you handsome devil. Joe performs his ritual as he speaks, but more relaxed, faintly laughing at himself with Ratso. The wall mirror h been added since we last saw the flat, along with a legle overstuffed chair with burnt-out cushions, a tasselled ta cover, pinups, calendar girls and several new Florida tou posters, Ratso moves to Joe's side, arranging the neckerchief, nodding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad -- for a cowboy -- you're okay, you're okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'm gonna do, I'm gonna make a cowboy outta you, kid. How about that? Build you up a little, teach you couple little tricks'n turn y'out to stud, Rat-stuff. Joe slaps his hat on Ratso's head, tilts it, hooks Ratso' thumbs in his jeans and shoves a cigarette into the corne Ratso's mouth. Ratso laughs till he chokes -- for one instant, self-consciously, mimicking Joe -- then removes hat and reaches for his threadbare black raincoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you got yourself one handsome, sweet-smelling cowboy, strut your stuff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Ratso peer down through a basement bay window, in the office of THE PERFECT GENTLEMAN ESCORT SERVICE -- endorsed by leading travel agencies and credit clubs offe discreet companionship and personal guided tours in any language. A large-busted matron, on a French phone, fills a memo and hands it to an immaculate young ESCORT, who sl the memo into his topcoat pocket as he comes from the off and hails a cab. Ratso darts forward, limping exaggerated holding the door, lifting the memo as he brushes off the Escort's topcoat. The young man waves him away with out a tip. Ratso slams the door and bites his thumb after the c unfolding the memo as he joins Joe on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like that? Cheap bastard... (reads, then) I think we struck gold. This is one high-class chick. The Barbizon for Women!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mutual of New York tower flashes MONY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso consults the memo as he speaks into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. McNeill, I'm calling for Miss Beecham at the Barbizon Hotel for Women. She won't need you tonight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A doorman helps a young lady into a limousine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you believe a whole goddam hotel with nothing but lonely chicks? Joe and Ratso watch from across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Score once in that setup, the way chicks talk, Christ... Joe cracks his gum, tilts his hat, starts across the stre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the money! Remember Cass Trehune? Cash! These rich bitches write a check at night, call the bank and stop payment in the morning. Get the cash! In Ratso's eyes -- as Joe enters the hotel -- its facade suddenly wipes away to reveal rich ladies in negligee wai in every room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe starts up the stairs, two at a time. A BELLHOP grabs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! No men upstairs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso warms his hands at a chestnut vendor's cart, seeing ... zoom close-up, a lady in a window grabbing Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe picks up a house phone, watched by the Bellhop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso sees Joe zip from room to room in wild animation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lobby watches Joe blow a gum bubble at the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring at a window display of Florida sportswear, Ratso' imagination soars, seeing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Ratso, like a model in a travel poster, in gaudy spor shirt, talking on the phone against a background of hotel ... Ratso like James Bond, surrounded by bikinis, dictati while girls serve coconut milk and massage his game leg.. ... Ratso like George Raft, in evening clothes, running a posh casino, flicking a coin... ... Ratso simply himself, dressed as he is, sitting on th beach, at peace in the sun... ... the same identical picture with Joe sitting beside Ra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe faces MISS BEECHAM, a reserved and rather plain young lady in evening dress, She tries to speak softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid there's been a terrible mistake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso leans against the window, flipping a coin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Beecham is flushed with humiliation, the entire lobb watching Joe in the hands of two bellboys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my money, goddamit, you owe me my money whether you get laid or not, lady, shee-it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights in the window suddenly switch off, blacking ou Florida. Ratso glances toward the growl of a siren O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police prowl car slows in front of the hotel. Ratso swi across the street with incredible speed to meet Joe as he tossed onto the sidewalk. Ratso picks up the Stetson and brushes it off, then helps Joe to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a high angle -- the two figures move slowly along th deserted avenue, their rhythmic musical duet growing more more faint in the distance, a broken grasshopper and a si foot tarnished cowboy -- passing a tuxedo rental store, n to a lighted sign -- TEMPERATURE IN MIAMI BEACH, FLORIDA DEGREES -- their pace slowing to a dead stop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Joe and Ratso frozen -- rain on the X windowpane free into sheet ice. O.S. a radio commercial plays warm, sentimental music while a voice explains how easy it is to heat with Humble oil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Ratso frozen in a narrow shaft of sunlight, watch the huge metal ball demolish the building next door. O.S. radio announcer sells FROZEN SUNSHINE ORANGE JUICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Ratso frozen, staring significantly at Joe's radi O.S. a singing commercial, "Don't wheeze and sneeze the winter away! Drink Frozen sunshine every day!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window -- Joe and Ratso watch the pawnbroker examine Joe's radio, "Be healthier, wealthier, life can b fine, when you drink Frozen" -- Sunshine is clicked off b the pawnbroker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Ratso frozen, wrapped in blankets as... ... the canned heat dies with a faint puff... ... water dripping in the tub-sink freezes into an icicle ... the candle burns down and out, leaving the screen dar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Ratso warm themselves on the smoke and steam risi from a subway grating -- watching two officials in fur collared coats inspect the front of their X flat building Reading their doom, Joe and Ratso, continue on, disappear into the subway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe stands alone, watching the midnight cowboys ply their trade. Camera pulls back as Joe turns away and enters a s front blood bank, offering ten dollars to blood donors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge hypodermic fills the frame, sucking Joe's blood. O Ratso coughs uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso leans over the tub-sink, dry-heaving while he cough wearing a sheepskin coat much too large for him. He contr the cough with effort -- hearing the door open and close -- wipes his mouth and turns to grin at... ... Joe, trying to light the empty Sterno can, deliberate ignoring Ratso. Ratso shrugs, washes his mouth at the fau finds a cigarette butt and lights it, careful to avoid inhaling the first puff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shee-it. Cough yourself inside out, then light a fag, a goddam fag. You make me puke. Where'd you steal it? In the movies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coat? A guy I did a favor once gave it to me. Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd you ever do a favor for? You just let some poor bastard freeze to death, wouldn't you? Joe slams ten dollars on the table. Ratso glances at Joe curious concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd that come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-second Street. Where'n hell you think it come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna know the truth? You dumb bastard, I got it for you. Look at it. Goddam thing's ten sizes too big for me. Ratso pulls off the coat and throws it at Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wear it yourself. I wouldn't put it on my back. Joe throws it back at Ratso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamned if I'll wear it! Ratso hurls it in a corner. Joe shoves the ten at Ratso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go get your medicine. Before you die on my goddam, hands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High angle -- Joe and Ratso cross an foot, chilled by win neither wearing the sheepskin coat. The Queens riverfront factories appear cold and bleak, deserted on Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera moves into acres of tombstones, piled like low-ren housing projects for the dead, the various faiths segrega by crumbling boundaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shee-it. I hate boneyards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So split. He ain't your goddam, father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso leads Joe past a Negro family at a grave -- glances around -- snatches an elaborate floral piece from a heads and hides it under his black raincoat as he darts toward low dividing wail and swings himself over into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... an endless section of plain stone markers. Joe touche his hat to two nuns, guiltily hurrying to overtake Ratso ibis father's grave, indistinguishable from the other gra except for the name on the headstone. Ratso places the fl piece on the grave with almost absurd solemnity. Joe laug

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kee-rist, you sure are one twisty little bastard, Ratso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name's Rico, at my own father's grave, a man deserves some respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Respect shee-it! You even steal flowers for his grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can he smell the difference, eh? Joe reads from the ribbon on the floral display.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh, he dam well know he ain't 'be-loved Aunt Winifred'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't read. Even dumber than you. Couldn't write his own name. X -- that's what it ought to say there on that goddam headstone. One big lousy X like our flat. Condemned. By order of City Hall. Joe is frowning, standing at the,headstone, momentarily depressed with an undefined sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Grammaw Sally Buck, she died without letting me know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window, past the FOR RENT sign, the tarnishin driers are lined up like tombstones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe frowns, puzzled, as Ratso pulls out a black skullcap, leading Joe toward a group of professional mourners, whispering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just keep your hat on and cry a little. They tip you when it's over. Joe and Ratso join the mourners as the funeral moves to t grave, Ratso mouthing an authentic double-talk... ... Joe standing self-consciously, aware of the covert glances of the other mourners, automatically reaching up remove his hat, remembering when Ratso elbows him in the ribs... ... Joe scowling, tight-lipped, embarrassed by the tip th is thrust in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A weary Santa Claus, in a rented beard and over-large costume, warms his hands over the steam of his coffee cup Joe and Ratso are arguing farther down the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just ain't right, cheating someone dead and can't cheat back. In the background, as Ratso speaks, HANSEL and GRETEL MACALBERTSON enter the lunch counter, inspecting the customers one by one. Both wear black turtlenecks and jea dressed as twins, both blond and pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and my old man. Same kinda mind. Putting me down till the day he died... (mimics) ... why can't you be like your brothers? Sons a father could be proud of. Yeah, sure. My brothers. Too goddam busy making something of themselves to show up when the old man's dying! Conditioned reflex, Ratso starts to cough. Joe sees the MacAlbertsons in the mirror, standing behind him, studyin him. Gretel nods, Hansel hands Joe a large black card, smiling vaguely, then moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that all about? Joe studies the black card, frowning at first, suddenly smiling, turning as if to call after the MacAlbertsons, b they are disappearing around the corner. Joe hands the ca to Ratso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna read something, read this. I been invited somewhere. Shocking pink letters on the black card read YOU ARE INVI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They picked me. The only one in the whole goddam place. You see how they looked me over, up and down before they give me that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? Joe sees a young man washing cups behind the counter. Joe shakes his head, wonderingly, turning to study himself in mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this thought just struck me. It wasn't too long ago I was washing dishes way the hell somewhere in Texas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm here. I'm in New York City. Getting picked for things. Don't you see what I'm driving at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you're driving at, you want me to get lost so you can go to your fancy-ass party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I say that? Did I?  (studies card) It don't say nothing about you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say nothing about you either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they picked me, right? So what I'll do, I'll just say, now look, you want me? Well, I don't go nowhere without my buddy here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Well, what the hell, I got nothing better to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow swirls in the aureole of a street light as Joe and R run, heads lowered, turning into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... a drab entrance hall, dimly lit -- signs identifying various commercial tenants -- a pink-on-black placard rea MACALBERTSON, TWO FLIGHTS UP. Joe has started up before h notices Ratso, leaning on the bannister at the foot of th stairs, struggling to catch his breath. His face and hair wet with perspiration, his lips lavender-blue. In swift flashes -- intercut -- Joe reads the panic in Ratso's eyes, so intense that Joe shares it, unable to sp or offer reassurance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better dry your hair some. You sweating all over the goddam place. Joe pulls out his shirttail, grabs Ratso by the neck and his head dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a comb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't need a comb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Few dozen cooties won't kill me, don't guess. Joe hands Ratso his own comb. Ratso swipes at his tangled hair angrily until two teeth break in the comb. He hands comb back, tugs at his hair with his fingers, pats it in place, then looks back into Joe's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay? I look okay? In a moment of silence, distant sounds can be heard -- a siren, the grinding teeth of a garbage truck, the twang o electric guitar upstairs at the party -- then Ratso makes quick gesture of impatience and starts up the stairs, pul himself on the bannister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bank of lights blinds Joe and Ratso as they enter -- electronic rock blasts their ears -- a bearded cameraman step-ladder photographs them as they stand confused -- fa a monstrous collage of tabloid photos blown up, showing t murder of a hippie known as Groovy -- in-huge black lette LOVE WAS GROOVY -- GROOVY IS DEAD. Joe shouts over the amplified music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better get a hold of someone and tell them I'm here. Ratso points to his ear -- he can't hear -- following Joe across the room. The huge loft is crowded with a random selection, gathered to serve as dress extras in an underground film. The party is the scene. The MacAlbertso merely supply the ingredients and allow it to happen, wit cameras strategically placed to record the happening... ... Hansel with tape recorder, Gretel with hand-held came drifting through the crowd -- catching words and images i detached, whimsical fashion. Gretel turns her camera on J and Ratso as they approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I made it. This here is Ratso Rizzo and I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rico. Rico Rizzo. Gretel smiles without recognition. Hansel gestures vaguel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need anything? I mean there's beer and so forth. Whatever your thing is... The twins move away together, pausing to confer with the operator of a tripod camera -- focused on an emaciated fl girl with long hair and dirty feet, stretched in a sarcophagus, clutching a dead daffodil, her eyes glazed. Scrawled in huge letters on the wall over her head -- LOV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want the word on that brother and sister act, I'll give you the word. That Hansel's a fag and Gretel's got the hots for herself. So who cares, right? Load up on the salami... Ratso heads for the refreshment table. Joe starts after h but pauses, intrigued by an alcove under the balcony wher light show is in progress -- surreal images of naked bodi projected against abstract currents of color and strobe light... ... a bored fat lady in a muu-muu, squatted like a Buddha a low table, rolling joints for the guests. She lights a joint and offers it to Joe as he wanders in watch the show. Joe laughs delightedly when he realizes w it is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shee-it, this is one helluva party! ... glancing around at the others, imitating their techni -- the quick inhaler, who follows with sharp gulps of air the deep inhalers who draw air as they inhale -- the styl who lets the smoke drift out and inhales through the nost -- Joe puffing himself slightly dizzy, starting to laugh the silent flick effect of the strobe light -- the action around him slowing almost imperceptibly, overcranked -- a veil of smoke hanging over the fat woman's face, transfor her into a laughing witch -- a similar veil around Joe's head, relaxing the self-conscious tension of his face, spontaneously curious about the play of light on his hand grinning at... ... a serious young technician handling the light show, scattering psychedelic stars across a sky of magenta fles ... Joe reaching for the stars as he rises and wanders ba to the crowded loft, fascinated to see... ... a crew with cameras and lights, on the balcony at one of the loft, photographing the scene below... ... a dark-haired lady by the name of SHIRLEY -- chic in style of a gangster's moll -- drinking beer from the bott predatory eyes searching the crowd... ... Ratso surreptitiously stuffing his pockets from the buffet table, glancing nervously over his shoulder, unawa of Gretel and her hand-held camera, photographing Ratso a steals, turning away casually, disinterested... ... Joe laughing as he dances for a moment with a tall bl girl -- the lights swinging around them -- faces swimming ... Shirley in fleeting close-up, gone in an instant, reappearing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... her face in the mirror smiling in a dark, provocative -- Joe standing at the bathroom door, forgetting to be embarrassed as Shirley turns away from the mirror, unhurriedly, running her fingers through her hair, boldly meeting Joe's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll we do? Leave now or what? Your place or mine? Oh God, the second I looked at you I knew. Did you? Joe grins, watching Shirley's lips move, unable to keep h in sync, startled to hear Ratso's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's hooked...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe realizes he is back at the party, Ratso whispering hoarsely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I'd say she was good for ten bucks, but I'll ask for twenty... But Joe is watching with terrible fascination as Hansel a Gretel lift the flower girl from her sarcophagus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know? We were going to make it? Joe glances down to see himself flanked by Ratso and Shir

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really want to do business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's he? Oh God! Don't tell me you two are a couple -- ? The flower girl, hypnotically dazed, accepts a broom dipp in black paint and smears a huge X across LOVE. Joe laugh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you laughing, Joe? Hansel holds a microphone toward Joe, who shrugs, grinnin Ratso and Shirley. Gretel's camera moves down Joe's body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you for real, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I ain't a f'real cowboy, but I'm one hell of a stud! Shirley glances at Ratso, who nods, whispering in her ear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very expensive stud. And I happen to be his manager. The scene -- from Joe's viewpoint -- becomes increasingly confusing and fragmented, dialogue and image moving in an out of focus, cameras and lights surrounding him, keeping center of attention in his own blown mind... ... Shirley's eyes unnaturally bright, inspecting his bod lingering on his thighs, moistening her lips...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too much -- to come face to face with a walking talking sex fantasy -- to buy a man's -- God! ... the tall black girl dancing in stroble light, startin remove her clothes -- Gretel following her with a camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait to tell my man Monday. I should be taking notes. Look at my arm! ... Shirley's talon-like fingernails caressing the goosef on her tanned arm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta sit down. I feel crummy. Ratso stretched out on a Victorian love seat -- the flowe girl walking unsteadily, passing out dead daffodils, plac one in Ratso's hand Gretel photographing his reaction...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat it -- a man in your line of work has to keep his strength up... ... Shirley bringing Joe a massive sandwich on a paper pl watching him bite into it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fantastic, now I know, everything you do has sexual implications. If I you know, bought it -- could I take pictures of you naked? That's part of it, isn't it, kinky kinda things? ... the tall black girl and a few others are trying to promote an orgy. A scrofulous old wino dances spastically working his toothless gums, preparing to expose himself t two girls dancing together...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want you, Joe. You've been chosen. ... five youths stand beside the sarcophagus -- two sailo two cycle freaks, a weight-lifter -- waiting to be pallbearers. Joe joins them. All lights and cameras are turned on the slow funeral procession, carrying the flowe girl out of the loft to the tune of "Moonlight and Roses" Strobe light adds to the unreality of the scene...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a thing for him. Before I knew. Why should knowing make it more of a thing? ... Shirley talks to Gretel as she photographs the funera

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally I'll have to ask myself why a cowboy? And why a cowboy whore? But not tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirley is pulling her coat out of the pile on the bannis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incidentally, how much is this going to cost me anyway? Joe turns to Ratso, whose attention is fixed on the coats

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her, Ratso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty bucks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sold. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and taxi fare for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree. And for that service I charge one dollar taxi fare. She takes a dollar from her purse and hands it to Ratso, takes Joe's arm and starts down the stairs. Ratso lingers starting quickly through the coats, frisking them for loo change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the foot of the stairs, Shirley kisses Joe violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name's Joe. Which is fabulous. Joe could be anyone. Kiss me, Joe, move over, Joe, go away, Joe. It's just perfect. They glance up as Ratso appears, swinging down too rapidl the bannister. He misses a step and falls -- a clown's fa unable to stop but apparently not hurting himself. Shirle and Joe are laughing when Ratso lands at the foot of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fell. Hey, fella, you fell. Is he all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rises, mimics) Is he all right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you're awright, why you hanging on the bannister. Can you walk or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk? Naturally I can walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got taxi fare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you're all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) I said yeah! Yeah, yeah, yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Shirley are kissing. Shirley rolls away, flushed, fanning herself. Joe rolls down the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe leans out of the taxi window, waving his Stetson, bellowing at the snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoopee ti yi yo...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso makes his way slowly from the building to the curb, whistling between his teeth sharply, hailing a cab. The c slows to a stop. Then the driver sees Ratso, shifts into and drives on. Ratso bites his thumb after the cab, rests a moment on the lamp post, then starts painfully inching way along the deserted street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe lies on his back, staring fixedly at a fragile mobile hanging from the ceiling, stirring listlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That happens. Don't worry about it... Shirley leans on one elbow, looking at Joe sympatheticall fighting an almost irrepressible desire to laugh. Still avoiding Shirley's eyes, Joe finds a cigarette on the sid table, searches for matches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's something never happened to me before, you can bet your bottom dollar. Uh, where's the matches, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Top drawer. Maybe if you didn't call me ma'am, things would work out better. Joe finds the matches, lights up and lies back, staring a the mobile as he smokes, still not looking at Shirley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First goddam, time it ever quit on me. Fact. The repressed laugh finally breaks through. Shirley stifl it quickly as Joe sits up, looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm lying!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (controls herself) No. Of course not. Just something struck me funny... Close on Joe -- watching Shirley closely, reacting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just put myself in your shoes. I had this image of a bugler without a horn, a policeman without a stick, etcetera, etcetera and I... (giggles) I think I'd better shut up, I'm making it worse. Shirley composes her face, reaching out to touch Joe. But that doesn't help either. He reacts sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should take a little nap, see what happens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't sleepy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Scribbage! Extreme close-up of Joe -- frowning, puzzled...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shee-it... ... camera pulling back to show Joe concentrating on a ga spread out on the sheet, consisting of nine dice lettered all sides, the object being to build as many words as possible, Scrabble fashion, while a sand timer counts the seconds. Shirley watches Joe's efforts to think with sympathetic amusement. The only word Joe has composed so is MAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's pretty Freudian, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? It's a perfectly good word, ain't it. How much time I got? (glances up) Goddam sand thing drive you crazy. Kee-rist. Spelling never was a very strong point with me. Even in school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you didn't talk so much, maybe you could think more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talking helps. Don't talk, you get muddled in your head. Hey! Now you just look at this here! Joe spells out MONY, down from the M in MAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an E in MONEY. If that's your word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M-O-N-Y -- I'm right! That's just exactly how they spell it up there on that big building, bet you could see it from here. M-O-N-Y.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stifles giggle) Okay. Never argue with a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y -- what in hell starts with Y? Shirley slyly trails the tips of her fingernails across J chest as she leans over to study the game, breathing soft into his ear as she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can end in Y day, pay, lay -- hey, pay lay! One predatory hand rests on his knee -- as if by accident disarranging the sheet, talon nails lightly brushing his thigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it out. That's cheating, teasing me so I can't think. Just one bitsy Y word and I gonna beat you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna beat me, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat your butt, you don't lemme think!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gay ends in Y. Fey. You like that -- gay fey -- is that your problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I show you what problem -- But the end of his sentence is swallowed by Shirley, taki his kiss in her open mouth, crushed by its impact, an ani noise snarling deep in her throat -- the agonized alley c wail of pleasure -- Joe's problem is solved. Joe's love t swells triumphant. At the same time, Shirley half-rises, trying to force Joe's head down, her own on top. The issu joined. Shirley has named the game. Her objective is to f Joe onto his back. Joe's objective is to retain his initiative. Camera ignores the classic action on the cent front, concentrating exclusively on peripheral tactical maneuvers... ... Joe's elbows pinning her shoulders... ... her eyes bright, accepting the challenge... ... his tight smile revealing clenched teeth... ... her fingers searching out then tickling his underarm. ... Joe laughing as he falls lopsidedly... ... Shirley laughing triumphantly... ... his hand closing on her wrist... ... her talon-nails clawing the air... ... her toes walking up his calf... ... her legs suddenly locking around his knees... ... her free hand grabbing his hair... ... her shoulder rising as she forces his head back... ... her lips pressing down on his... ... his hand swatting an unidentified mass of flesh... ... her eyes popping, teeth clamping his ear lobe... ... his hand catching her ankle... ... her teeth losing the ear lobe as she screams... ... her foot appearing upside down beside her face... ... her talon-nails furrowing flesh, drawing blood... ... his head rearing back, roaring... ... both rolling to the floor, out of view... ... her feet suddenly flying up into view... ... her hand tugging rhythmically at the blanket... ... her other hand wildly exploring Joe's back... ... her ankles locking spasmodically... ... her eyes and mouth wide, gaping... ... the blanket suddenly ripping free, flying into the ai her arm flings itself around Joe... ... the bedclothes spilling down around them, muffling he ascending shrieks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoopee ti yi yo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirley has difficulty reverting to her nine-to-five role a Madison Avenue career girl. Half-dressed for work, she talking on the telephone, her eyes on the open door to th bathroom, through which Joe's voice continues singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I really can't talk now, if you know what I mean, but believe me when I say, Myra, it's an experience every emancipated woman owes herself. I'm not. I'm not exaggerating. Well, what's Phil's poker night? (yells off) Joe -- are you available next Thursday, eight-thirty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thoroughly shaved, bathed and groomed, Joe is sprinkling expensive cologne into his boots. He yells back enthusiastically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, lemme think now, Thursday, eight-thirty, yeah, I guess I could be available. Hell, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirley turns back to the phone. Joe appears, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just come here? I'll be working every night this week. I'll leave a key with the super...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, ma'am -- Shirley -- I sure hate to trouble you, but... Shirley opens her purse, savoring the moment. As she plac the money in Joe's hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Joe slaps a bill on the counter, admiring a fine new cowboy shirt in the mirror, wriggling new white socks int his boots. Suddenly remembering, he goes to the sock rack buys two pairs, one large and one small. Gradually dominating, Joe's love theme recurs, continuing over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Joe slaps down money to pay for an assortment of medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe takes the stairs two at a time to burst in on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Ratso huddled in the overstuffed chair -- wearing the stolen sheepskin coat -- wrapped in blankets, his teeth chattering, in spite of the sweat on his forehead. Joe st abruptly, his mood shattered by Ratso's alarming conditio They simply stare at each other for a moment, then Joe tu away to see soup heating on the Sterno stove. Joe tosses of his paper bags onto Ratso's lap...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what you think of that crap. I'll pour your soup. Got some of that junk you like to swill, too. Mentholatum. Aspirin. All that shee it... Ratso opens the paper bag, trying to control his shiverin pulling out the socks and a suit of long underwear. He se Joe watching him for a reaction. The best Ratso can do is slight shake of his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But while you was buying the underwear, I could have lifted the socks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't lift fly specks from a sugar bowl. Can you hold this? Joe hands Ratso the soup. Ratso seems steadied by the war in his hands. He nods, sipping the soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But thanks. (hesitates, then) Hey, Joe, don't get sore about this or anything. You promise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't think I can walk. (embarrassed) I mean, I been falling down a lot and, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll happen. I mean what they do to, you know, do with you -- if you can't -- ah, Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Cops. Or the -- how should I know? Ratso is trembling so violently that the sou, starts to s over. Joe takes it and sets it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Here it is. You gonna go see the doctor. I got nine bucks and twenty more Thursday and I gonna be riding high before you know it. So you gonna get you the best goddam doctor in this town and get yourself straightened out, that's what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doctors. No, sir. Not me. Doctors are like goddam auto mechanics. Fix one-thing, unplug another. Operate for piles and while they're there, they unscrew your liver. My old man, for God's sake, wasn't any sicker'n I am when he went to the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, just exactly what the hell you think you're gonna do? Die on me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to Florida, that's my only chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what's wrong with you? You got fevers. You kinky as a bedbug. How you gonna get to Florida?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll find the money. If you just get me on the bus, that's all I ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just when everything's going my way, you gotta pull a stunt like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even want you to go. Whaddya think of that? I got other plans for my life than dragging around some dumb cowboy that thinks he's God's gift to women. One twenty-buck trick and he's already the biggest stud in New York City. It's laughable. Joe sets his Stetson on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I put you on that bus down to Florida tonight, that'll be the happiest day of my life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe strikes a match with his thumbnail and watches it cur away while he waits, hearing a phone ring. Then the phone answered by a woman's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Shirley... Miss who? Oh, yeah, well, when will Missus Gardner be home? ... I'm a friend of hers, a goddam good friend... Shee-it, I can't wait till then... Joe hangs up while the answering service's voice is still talking. The match has burned out. Joe flips it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headline -- WALTER P. BOX TAKES NEW YORK BY SURPRISE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe loiters outside a gag headline print shop, his eyes following a man in homburg and chesterfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe lingers momentarily, identifying with the violence in jazz drummer, his eyes searching for a pickup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe tests his skills in a shoot-down with a large metal cowboy and kills him, a recorded voice sneaks, "Got me!" the cowboy slumps. Joe glances off as he hears polite applause...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo... ... TOWNY -- a stout, round-faced man -- clasps Joe's han between both of his own, like an old friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you? (more quietly) Townsend P. Locke, from Chicago. Call me Towny. I'm here to attend a paper manufacturers' convention and, frankly, to have a little fun, dammit... Towny grips Joe's elbow, almost forcibly leading him away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Towny's face appears huge at Joe's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my first night in town and I'll consider it a ghastly omen clouding my entire ten days, if you don't consent to have dinner with me. Anywhere you like... Towny's mouth continues speaking at an incredible rate, b his words are drowned out momentarily by the grinder of a sanitation truck, chewing up a discarded Christmas tree w tinsel clinging to it. Towny is still talking when they'v passed the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... never mind how you're dressed. They know me. I'll say you're with the rodeo. There's always a rodeo in New York, dammit. Besides, you look very elegant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe hardly notices O'Daniel on a far cornet, his whining scarcely audible. "Ye are the salt of the earth, Jesus said, but if the sal hath lost its savor, wherewith shall it be salted?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, dammit all, I just remembered, we'll have to eat in my room because I have this phone call coming at nine-thirty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ancient open cage lift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I like about you, you're such a wonderful conversationalist. So won't that be nice to have dinner sent up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A threadbare, carpeted but spacious hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty years ago this was the only hotel in Manhattan. My mother always calls me at her bedtime, so I've got to be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room has little to recommend it except its size and l French window, through which -- ignored by Joe -- the Mut tower flashes MONY. Towny waves Joe toward the couch, qui slipping several physical culture magazines from the coff table onto a shelf beneath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drink? I've got some nice gin. If you'd prefer something else, they'll send it up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gin's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so exciting. New York. The mad forward thrust of everything. My sense of time here is completely altered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe carries Ratso down the stairs, wrapped in a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffee table is littered with empty cartons of Chines food, soaked through with brown sauce. Joe finds the last roll and eats it as Towny's voice drones on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes it seems to me time stopped twenty years ago. There was this war, there was this handsome young man with quite black hair and he was supposed to die. But he didn't. Isn't that amusing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Towny's dialogue moves out of sync. Towny's eyes seem to into camera -- from Joe's viewpoint -- but slightly past The quality of the scene grows increasingly disjointed as glances around the room, looking for something to steal, losing personal contact with Towny, viewing him as an obj to be used for a specific purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough about me. I'm through talking for the evening. Now I want to hear about conditions in the West. The romance of the West holds a tremendous power over me. Mother was actually a pioneer woman, can you believe it? When she calls, I'll introduce you and she'll be so thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso sits an a stoop while Joe hails a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Towny's voice is only a shrill monotone from here, Joe searches with increasing desperation for something of val An old electric razor is too bulky for Joe's pocket, prob worthless anyhow. Towny's array of medicines merely recal Joe's purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, a coincidence. Guess who was being discussed. Discussed. Not disgusted. Discussed! Do you have that thing turned up? Why aren't you wearing it! This is impossible!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe lifts Ratso from the taxi and carries him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Towny, did I mention I got a sick kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is rehearsing the speech in the bathroom mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he is, he's sicker'n shee-it. And I've gotta get him South quick as I can...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe stands in a long line, glancing impatiently at the cl while Ratso waits on a bench, wrapped in his blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Towny is stretched out on the couch, staring morosely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was so childish with her. Joe moves into frame past camera, standing in front of hi so that we can see the scene from behind Joe's waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you got me up here for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, difficult, it's so difficult. You're a nice person, Joe -- I should never have asked you up -- a lovely person. Oh, how I loathe life. I loathe it. Please go. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, yes. No, I mean yes please go. Help me to be good. Come back tomorrow. Promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to Florida.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is terrible. I meet someone who -- then -- wait, I want to give you a present. For your trip. You'll let me please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's face is expectant, next in line at the ticket windo He nods reassuringly toward Ratso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's face is puzzled then angry as Towny takes a Saint Christopher medal from his sack and hands it to Joe. His are looking past Joe, his speech out of sync.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please take it. You don't have to be Catholic. Saint Christopher is the patron saint of all travelers. I want you to have it. For helping me be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Joe's turn. The clerk looks at him expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe's voice is angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I gotta have money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes. Of course. I should have thought. You shouldn't have to ask. That was thoughtless of me. Yes. Wait here... Towny hurries across the room to the bedside table. Besid the telephone is a picture of a prosperous pioneer woman wearing a hearing-aid. Towny tries to conceal his movements as he takes a wallet from the drawer, lifts out a bill and tucks the wallet ba and turns -- terrified to see Joe close behind him -- alm knocking the lamp off the table in his fright. Pressed against the table, protecting but calling attention to hi wallet, Towny holds out the bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Don't even thank me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes the bill) I gotta have more'n ten. I gotta have fifty-seven dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I simply don't have it, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get outta my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wasting your time. There's nothing in there. Towny clutches the table, staring at Joe, shaking his hea like a bad little boy. Joe backhands him angrily. Trying duck the blow, Towny stumbles and slips to the floor, but grabs the table in his arms, watching Joe out of the corn of his eyes, whimpering. Joe grabs his hair, turning his up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go. Let go of the table. Joe slaps him, but Towny clings more fiercely to the tabl Joe tries to jerk it free. Joe strikes him with his fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I deserved that, I know I did. But he clutches the table wildly. His mother's picture fa unnoticed. Joe stands in panic, sickened, unable to fulfi the role Towny has assigned him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought this on myself. I'm bleeding, my nose is bleeding, isn't it? Towny's eyes shine, teeth clenched in a crazy smile, bloo trickling from his nose. Suddenly Joe jerks the lamp free its socket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna gimme fifty-seven dollars or you wanna busted skull? Towny simply stares at the lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please let go of that table. Joe threatens, swings the lamp down, but stops short of hitting Towny. Towny shrieks -- eyes rolling back as he f limp -- loosing his grip on the table, leaning on the bed laughing and crying hysterically. Joe has to step over hi reach the wallet in the drawer. He takes all the money -- probably twice what he needs -- desperate to get out of t room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe carries Ratso up the steps onto the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Towny's shrill little whisper says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Joe. ... provoking Joe to glance back. Towny is reaching for t telephone, his eyes on Joe with wild brightness, holding hand on the receiver. Joe knocks the phone from his hand, hits Towny in the mouth, jerks the cord from the wall as Towny falls -- gagging -- finally dislodging his dentures the carpet. Joe stands sick and confused, holding the use phone in two hands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus driver revs the powerful engine, shifting gears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Joe is about to hang the dead receiver on its hook wh on sudden impulse -- he shoves the small end of the recei into the toothless mouth of the man on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus roars into the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Ratso sit near the rear of the bus. Ratso's teeth chatter, wrapped in the blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-one hours. They ride a few moments in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trip is. Nine-thirty in the morning we get there. Not this morning but the next one at nine thirty. Both nod for a moment in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These guys're good drivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gotta be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus tires sing as it speeds South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Ratso have reversed places, putting Ratso by the window. Joe watches a middle-aged couple try on their new straw hats, unaware that Joe is watching them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get your first palm tree in South Carolina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'n hell a dumb Bronx kid like you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shee-it. You believe all you read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The metal grating rings as the bus soars onto it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two aging young ladies in brand-new resort wear are casua examining Joe, along with the other men on the bus, but J is frowning at Ratso, who shivers despite the bright sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you have to shiver, why don't you pull the blanket up more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been thinking. I hope we're not gonna have a lotta trouble about my name down there. Because like what's the whole point of this trip anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep the goddam blanket on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean New York's one thing, but can you see this guy, imagine it, running around the goddam beach all suntan and he's going in swimming, like, and then somebody yells 'Hey, Ratso' -- how does that sound to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like they knew you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like crap, admit it. And I'm not gonna have it. I'm Rico all the time, okay, do you blame me? That's agreed, okay? We're gonna tell all these new people my name's Rico? Joe nods. Ratso closes his eyes, momentarily at peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus passes a Florida hotel sign too swiftly to read i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe frowns in his sleep, awakens, lifts his Stetson to se Ratso wide awake, in misery, wiping tears from his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- whatsa matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible) I'm wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wet my pants! My seat's all wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, don't cry about it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here I am going to Florida and my leg hurts, my butt hurts, my chest hurts, my face hurts, and like that ain't enough, I gotta pee all over myself. Joe laughs suddenly, uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm falling apart, that's funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, laughing) You just -- just -- what happened, you just had a little rest stop wasn't on the schedule. Ratso begins to laugh with Joe as if it were the funniest thing they'd ever heard. Then Ratso's face pales as he st to choke and cough. Joe pats him on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what size pants you wear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus is parked in the distance. Joe comes from a cloth store, bare-headed, wearing plain slacks and sport-shirt. carries the boots, Stetson and cowboy suit in one hand, a bundle under his arm. He dumps his cowboy regalia in the trash bin of a sandwich stand and calls to the WAITRESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple crullers'n coffee to go. The Waitress draws coffee, wraps crullers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York. Joe pays. She smiles, gives him change. Joe smiles, start toward the bus, hardly aware that he has accomplished something rare and remarkable for Joe -- a simple human contact without fear or threat, a pleasant everyday happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Ratso have moved to the seat farthest back, wider than the others. Joe blocks the view of the other passeng as he helps Ratso into a new pair of corduroy pants and a Florida shirt. In the middle of the operation, Ratso doze off. Joe shakes his head, scowling, annoyed, but continue lifting Ratso enough to slide the pants around his waist. Ratso awakens as Joe zips the fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what the hell you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm zipping your fly, what the hell you think I'm doing? They both smile. It isn't funny enough to laugh at. Joe arranges the blanket, takes out a package of cigarettes, glances at Ratso and puts it away.

dialogues.speaker: BUS
dialogues.text: Palm trees are streaking past the window. The sun is glar hot. A group of kids in bare feet and straw hats wave to bus as it passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ratso's eyes squint in a dazed half-sleep. Joe leans acro to pull down the shade. He hesitates a moment, watching.. ... past his reflection, a group of young men on their wa work, carrying lunch pails, dressed exactly as Joe is now dressed... ... then Joe lowers the blind and seats himself. Ratso no slightly, his voice practically inaudible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shee-it, you know, I got this thing all figured out, Ratso. I mean Rico. When we get to Miami, what I'll do, I'll go to work. I gotta do that, 'cause see, I ain't no kind of a hustler. I ain't even any goddam good as a bum. I'm a nothing, that's what I am. So reckon I'd better go to work and get me a goddam job. Okay? Joe glances at Ratso, but there is no response. Surreptitiously, Joe takes out a cigarette, turns his fac away from Ratso and lights it, hiding it cupped in his ha as he smokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, guess that's what I'm gonna do. They ride for a moment in semi-darkness, Joe smoking, loo at the other people on the bus, brighter without the shad down. Joe turns, checking the blanket around Ratso, notic that Ratso is sitting in a peculiarly stiff, awkward position. Joe leans over to straighten Ratso's head, bloc our view for a moment. Then Joe leans back, frowning, thoughtful. We still do not see Ratso's face. Joe rises slowly, starting forward in the bus... ... passing an older couple, a schoolgirl, two ladies wit straw hats, a young man trying to read, pausing when he reaches... ... the DRIVER, staring out at the Sunshine Parkway with Driver, leaning over so he won't have to speak too loudly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend's dead in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your friend's what in the back seat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead. Dead as a doornail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this some kind of... He glances at Joe, then pulls off the road and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, folks, everything's fine. Nothing to worry about. The passengers crane their necks as Joe follows the Drive the rear of the bus. The passengers at the rear are stari ahead, trying not to see what is going on. The Driver tou Ratso, straightens, touches his hat, but doesn't remove i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he kin to you? Joe nods no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to close his eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just reach over and close them. That's all. Joe closes Ratso's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we'll just drive on, right? Nothing else to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. Not till Miami. I'll see to burying then. The Driver moves to the front and turns to the passengers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little sickness, folks, nothing serious. We'll be in Miami... (looks at watch) ... in forty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits stiffly, very frightened, as the bus starts on. he glances at Ratso, frowning, reaches out an arm and put around Ratso, settling back, staring straight ahead.
